fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f \colon A \to B be a morphism in a regular category. Then for any two subobjects A' \rightarrowtail A and B' \rightarrowtail B, we have \exists _{f}(A' \cap f ^{*} (B')) \cong \exists _{f}(A') \cap B' in \mathsf { Sub } (B), where \exists _{f} is the left adjoint of f ^{*} constructed in .
By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf { Img } (f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B'))) \cong \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B'))) \cong \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B' as required.

A category \mathcal { C } is regular iff it is cartesian and has images that commute with pullbacks, i.e., the following diagram commutes up to isomorphism for any object f \in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} , sw = { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} , ne = \mathsf { Sub } (B), se = \mathsf { Sub } (A), north = \mathsf { Img } , south = \mathsf { Img } , west = f ^{*} , east = f ^{*} , }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal { C } is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f \colon A \to B be a morphism and g \colon B' \twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Then note that \mathsf { Img } (g) is an isomorphism. Since images commute with pullbacks by hypothesis, we can form the following diagram.

Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f ^{*} ( \mathsf { Img } (g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf { Img } ( f ^{*} (g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f ^{*} (g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.

If \mathcal { C } is regular, then by , the unit \vartheta \colon \mathsf {id} \to \mathsf { Img } consists of covers. Let f \colon A \to B be any morphism in \mathcal { C } and g \colon B' \to B be an object in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}. By , g can be factored as \vartheta _{g} \mathsf { Img } (g). Form the following pullbacks. Note that since covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis, \widehat { \vartheta _{g}} is also a cover. Then by the pasting lemma, the composite f ^{*} ( \mathsf { Img } (g)) \circ \widehat { \vartheta _{g}} is isomorphic to f ^{*} (g) in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}}.
Thus, f ^{*} (g) admits another cover-mono factorization.
Then by uniqueness, C \cong \underline {A'}. Thus, \mathsf { Img } ( f ^{*} (g)) \cong f ^{*} ( \mathsf { Img } (g)).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \top \colon \Omega ' \to \Omega be the generic subobject of a category \mathcal { C } with pullbacks, then \Omega ' is terminal.
If \mathcal { C } has pullbacks then the assignment A \mapsto \mathsf { Sub } (A) can be extended to a pseudofunctor \mathsf { Sub } \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT }.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
It suffices to specify an action on morphisms. Let f \colon A \to B be an arbitrary morphism. Since monomorphisms are stable under pullback, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} restricts to a functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A). Then pseudofunctoriality follows from the following facts:
Let f \colon A \to B, g \colon B \to C, and m \colon C' \rightarrowtail C be given. By the pasting lemma of pullbacks, the pullback f ^{*} g ^{*} (m) is also a pullback along gf. Thus, the universal property of pullbacks guarantees that (gf) ^{*} (m) \cong f ^{*} g ^{*} (m) in \mathsf { Sub } (A).
The pullback against the identity is always an isomorphism. Thus, for any m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A, \mathsf {id} _{ A } ^{*} (m) \cong m in \mathsf { Sub } (A).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal { C } is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal { C } and m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } are inherited from \mathcal { C }.
